title: Two-Handed Sword for the Bodyguard of Julius, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and Prince of Wolfenbüttel (Politics, Status, Fashion: The Arms and Armor Collection)
transcript:
Narrator: Curator Jonathan Travares.

Jonathan Travares: This sword, as massive and impressive as it is, is really not as heavy as it looks. It weighs only about nine-and-a-half pounds. It also has a number on the blade immediately below the ring or the cross guard. It's an "N," and then it says "59," and that tells us, really, that this is number 59 of a whole series. We actually know how many swords there were. The highest number on a surviving sword is 290. If we can just imagine for a moment what 290 bodyguards holding these swords point up must've been like, what kind of symbol of power and wealth that put forward, signifying the status of Duke Julius.

Narrator: Professor of Medieval History, Jonathan Lyon.

Jonathan Lyon: So, Julius would have been one of these numerous different dukes who are nominally under the authority of the Holy Roman Emperor, and this is a very long name for a polity that was actually made up of very many smaller political entities with lots of different dukes, counts, bishops, archbishops all ruling over small political territories of their own.

Jonathan Travaras: At the top of the sword, the way it's displayed, the pommel, which is sort of in a crutch shape, we actually have an acronym that stands for the motto of the duke. And the letters read out O-H-B-M—N-M-D-S-L-V-E which actually translates from the German "Oh, Lord, protect--"

Jonathan Lyon: "Oh, Lord, protect my soul, life, and honor." This was very commonplace in the 16th century when politics, religion, and warfare were all intertwined with one another in ways that can be hard for us to imagine today.
